elements.desc: <google-signin> is used to authenticate with Google, allowing you to interact with other Google APIs such as Drive and Google+. If you do not need to show the button, use companion `` element to declare scopes, check authentication state. #### Examples #### Notes The attribute `clientId` is provided in your Google Developers Console (https://console.developers.google.com). The `scopes` attribute allows you to specify which scope permissions are required (e.g do you want to allow interaction with the Google Drive API). Many APIs also need to be enabled in the Google Developers Console before you can use them. The `requestVisibleActions` attribute is necessary if you want to write app activities (https://developers.google.com/+/web/app-activities/) on behalf of the user. Please note that this attribute is only valid in combination with the plus.login scope (https://www.googleapis.com/auth/plus.login). The `offline` attribute allows you to get an auth code which your server can redeem for an offline access token (https://developers.google.com/identity/sign-in/web/server-side-flow). Use label properties to customize prompts. The button can be styled in using the `height`, `width`, and `theme` attributes. These attributes help you follow the Google+ Sign-In button branding guidelines (https://developers.google.com/+/branding-guidelines). The `google-signin-success` event is triggered when a user successfully authenticates and `google-signed-out` is triggered when user signs out. You can also use `isAuthorized` attribute to observe user's authentication state. Additional events, such as `google-signout-attempted` are triggered when the user attempts to sign-out and successfully signs out. When requesting offline access, the `google-signin-offline-success` event is triggered when the user successfully consents with offline support. The `google-signin-necessary` event is fired when scopes requested via google-signin-aware elements require additional user permissions. #### Testing By default, the demo accompanying this element is setup to work on localhost with port 8080. That said, you *should* update the `clientId` to your own one for any apps you're building. See the Google Developers Console (https://console.developers.google.com) for more info.

properties.name: appPackageName
properties.desc:
App package name for android over-the-air installs.
See the relevant [docs](https://developers.google.com/+/web/signin/android-app-installs)

properties.name: brand
properties.desc: The brand being used for logo and styling.

properties.name: clientId
properties.desc: a Google Developers clientId reference

properties.name: cookiePolicy
properties.desc:
The cookie policy defines what URIs have access to the session cookie
remembering the user's sign-in state.
See the relevant [docs](https://developers.google.com/+/web/signin/reference#determining_a_value_for_cookie_policy) for more information.

properties.name: fill
properties.desc:
By default the ripple expands to fill the button. Set this to true to
constrain the ripple to a circle within the button.

properties.name: hasPlusScopes
properties.desc: True if *any* element has google+ scopes

properties.name: height
properties.desc:
The height to use for the button.

Available options: short, standard, tall.

properties.name: isAuthorized
properties.desc: True if authorizations for *this* element have been granted

properties.name: labelAdditional
properties.desc: An optional label for the button for additional permissions.

properties.name: labelSignin
properties.desc: An optional label for the sign-in button.

properties.name: labelSignout
properties.desc: An optional label for the sign-out button.

properties.name: needAdditionalAuth
properties.desc: True if additional authorization required globally

properties.name: offline
properties.desc: Allows for offline `access_token` retrieval during the signin process.

properties.name: raised
properties.desc: If true, the button will be styled with a shadow.

properties.name: requestVisibleActions
properties.desc:
The app activity types you want to write on behalf of the user
(e.g http://schemas.google.com/AddActivity)

properties.name: scopes
properties.desc:
The scopes to provide access to (e.g https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive)
and should be space-delimited.

properties.desc: Is user signed in?

properties.name: signIn
properties.desc:
Sign in user. Opens the authorization dialog for signing in.
The dialog will be blocked by a popup blocker unless called inside click handler.

properties.name: signOut
properties.desc: Sign out the user

properties.name: theme
properties.desc:
The theme to use for the button.

Available options: light, dark.

properties.name: width
properties.desc:
The width to use for the button.

Available options: iconOnly, standard, wide.

Many APIs also need to be enabled in the Google Developers Console before you can use them. The `requestVisibleActions` attribute is necessary if you want to write app activities (https://developers.google.com/+/web/app-activities/) on behalf of the user. Please note that this attribute is only valid in combination with the plus.login scope (https://www.googleapis.com/auth/plus.login).
